lines.text: Saw the game, kid. Tough break.
lines.character: Mike the Bartender at Universal Joint Bar

lines.text: You said it, mister. I blew it good.
Don't worry too much about it. Remember, you've got your whole life to look forward to. Things will work out just fine. Trust me.
lines.character: Mike the Bartender at Universal Joint Bar

lines.text:
[walking away]
Old fart. What the hell does he know?
35 years old, and my life is shit.
Can't be all that bad.
lines.character: Mike the Bartender at Universal Joint Bar

lines.text: It's not that it's bad, you know, it's just that it's ordinary.
So, Mike, do you do this a lot, I mean, you know, change peoples' lives and stuff?
I've been known to make a few adjustments now and again.
lines.character: Mike the Bartender at Universal Joint Bar

lines.text: How can my life change so much just because I hit one stinking baseball?

Well, you see Larry, one's destiny is a very complicated thing. Every incident in a person's life affects everything else that follows it. Instead of missing the baseball, however, you hit it. Then you became a hero, married the prom queen, and so on, and so forth, until you find yourself exactly where you are. So you see, hitting that baseball has spun your life off in an entirely new direction.
lines.character: Mike the Bartender at Universal Joint Bar

lines.text: Are you an angel or something?
Not exactly, no.
lines.character: Mike the Bartender at Universal Joint Bar

lines.text: Then what are you?
Have you ever been faced with a decision, and you weren't sure what to do?
lines.character: Mike the Bartender at Universal Joint Bar

lines.text: Yeah, sure, plenty of times.
And then something inside you made you choose one direction over another?
lines.character: Mike the Bartender at Universal Joint Bar

lines.text: Yeah. So?
So that's me. I make the suggestions, and you make the choices. That's how destiny works, Larry - very subtly. Welcome to your new life, Larry. I hope you like it.
lines.character: Mike the Bartender at Universal Joint Bar

lines.text: Is there anything else that's gonna come as a shock?
It all will, to some degree.
lines.character: Mike the Bartender at Universal Joint Bar

lines.text: To what degree?
You'll see. Things have changed, Larry. You have to take the bad with the good. You didn't think everything was gonna be perfect, did you?
lines.character: Mike the Bartender at Universal Joint Bar

lines.text: Well, I... I..., I suppose not.
This is your life, Larry. Learn to enjoy what you've got.
lines.character: Mike the Bartender at Universal Joint Bar

lines.text: You'll find a lot of people don't like you, Larry.
lines.character: Mike the Bartender at Universal Joint Bar

lines.text: Congratulations, Larry. It's a brave man who takes control of his own destiny.
lines.character: Mike the Bartender at Universal Joint Bar

lines.text: Your destiny has been changed, Larry, by request, I might add. And you must take responsibility for the circumstances of your new life. They are, after all, of your own making.
lines.character: Mike the Bartender at Universal Joint Bar

lines.text: Well, if I made 'em, I can unmake 'em!
Larry, if we had such a great life together, why'd you want it changed?

[pause]
I guess... I just didn't know what I had.
How well do you remember 1970?
I was wrong about you. I think you're a wonderful man. I wish it could've been different between us. I guess it just wasn't meant to be. Sorry.

[long pause as Ellen walks away]
Wait a minute, that's bullshit! It was meant to be!
Somebody here call for a tow truck?
Thanks. Thanks for everything. The good and the bad. Boy, you sure do know how to make a point. Oh, and listen, Mike - whatever you've got planned for the rest of my life? It's perfect.

[toasts]
Happy birthday, Larry.
lines.character: Mike the Bartender at Universal Joint Bar

lines.text: I wish I'd known it was your birthday, I would have gotten you something.
Well, Cindy Jo, you've already given me more than you could possibly know. Really.
[voice over]

Destiny's a pretty big concept, when you think about it. Where you are in life, how you got there, what would have happened if one thing or another had been different. To be honest, I never gave it much thought, myself, until today, June 14th, my 35th birthday, and without a doubt, the strangest day of my life. Do you remember the old story that starts, "This guy goes into a bar"? Well, I'm the guy, and here's the story.
[voice over]
Why is it when you do something terrific, nine times out of 10 you're all alone, but when you screw up really big, the whole world is watching?
Oh, honey, were you thinking about that silly baseball game again?
[voice over]
Why is it every time you have a mouthful of freeze-dried, your boss walks in on you?
When I played for the Bears, they used to call me "Cement Head". But you can call me Jackie.
[voice over]
Why is it every time your best friend's kissing you on the head, a beautiful woman comes along and catches you?
[voice over]
Maybe it was because it was my birthday. Maybe it was seeing Cindy Jo. I don't know. But all morning I'd been thinking about what it would have been like if my life had turned out differently.

Well, you know what your problem is? Nothing's ever good enough for you. Way I see it, you've got the perfect life. You've got a wonderful home, a terrific wife, a good job, and the best friend money can buy. What else could a guy want?
A little excitement would be nice.
You wouldn't want me to fork you to death, would you?
Sometimes I get the distinct feeling I'm missing out on something.
Well, what she's got - and she's got plenty you don't need.
You sure?

[pause]
Not absolutely. But if I ever tried to find out, your mother would kill me.
You're the dad every kid dreams of, you know that?
[voice over]
Why is it every time you break into your boss's office, he always walks in on you?
Lose something, Burrows?
Something tells me I have.
How about that! The desk is wired to my ass!

[Larry sits down on a chair in front of a desk with computers and is amazed by their self-working greetings]
How about that! The desk is wired to my ass.
[Suddenly the intercom calls in]
Good morning, sir.
Oh, hi! How are you?
Can I get you something, sir?
No, no, I'm fine. Oh! Coffee! I'd really like a cup of coffee.
Right away, sir. And Mr. Pender and Mr.Flick are on their way to see you, sir.
You're kidding? Those jerks still work here?
Larry, darling, your guests are wondering if you're all right? What's the matter, dear?
My parents are divorced.
Of course they are. Everybody's parents are divorced.
You know what my policy is? You do nothing, you see what happens.
Have you ever had any regrets, Clip? You know, about how your life is turned out, about the choices you made.
Nooo. Oh... no. I figured I didn't make out many choices. You know what my policy is? You do nothing, you see what happens. And you know what, things always are turning up fine.
Yeah, for you, Clip.
Guys like you make me look like a hotshot.
